content.title: Acute Compartment Syndrome
content.definition: A limb-threatening emergency occurring when elevated pressure within a closed muscle compartment compromises tissue perfusion, leading to muscle and nerve ischemia. Untreated, it progresses to irreversible muscle necrosis, contracture, and potential limb loss within 6-8 hours.

mechanism: Increased compartment contents (bleeding, edema) OR decreased compartment size
Tissue perfusion pressure = diastolic pressure - compartment pressure
When perfusion pressure falls below critical threshold, ischemia ensues

critical_threshold.clinical_significance: Delta pressure more reliable than absolute

time_course.onset: Can develop within 2-6 hours after insult
time_course.irreversible: Muscle necrosis begins at 4-6 hours of ischemia

vascular.reperfusion_injury: After arterial repair, especially with >4-6 hour ischemia

other: Drug overdose with prolonged limb compression

classic_6_ps.pain: Out of proportion, with passive stretch (EARLIEST and most reliable)
classic_6_ps.pulselessness: VERY LATE - often normal until advanced

key_points.pain: Pain on passive stretch of muscles in compartment is hallmark
key_points.pulses: PULSES ARE TYPICALLY PRESERVED until very late - don't rely on this
key_points.high_risk: Unconscious, intubated, or pain-controlled patients can't report

lower_leg.compartments: Anterior, lateral, deep posterior, superficial posterior
lower_leg.anterior: Most common - dorsiflexor weakness, first web space numbness

clinical.primary: High index of suspicion is critical
clinical.findings: Pain with passive stretch, tense compartment

wound_management.dressings: Negative pressure wound therapy often used
wound_management.closure: Delayed primary closure at 48-72 hours, or skin graft

learning_objectives: Recognize early clinical signs of compartment syndrome
Apply appropriate pressure thresholds for diagnosis
Perform timely fasciotomy to prevent permanent injury
clinical_pearls: Pain out of proportion with passive stretch is the EARLIEST sign
PULSES ARE PRESERVED until very late - don't wait for absent pulses
Delta pressure (diastolic - compartment) <30 mmHg is more reliable than absolute pressure
After arterial repair with >4-6 hour ischemia time, have low threshold for prophylactic fasciotomy
All 4 compartments of the leg must be released - don't miss the deep posterior
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Absent pulses are an early sign - Reality: Pulses are typically preserved until late stages
